MENELE.text:
System Setup is not complete.
Press Initial Setup to start setup.

System Setup is not complete.
Press End of Arm Tool Setup to start setup.

System Setup is not complete.
Press Cell Setup to start setup.
The required setups are not completed.

System Setup is not complete.
Press Torch Setup to start setup.
Select T1 on mode switch on the panel of controller.
Turn the Teach Pendant Enable switch to [ON].
Hold one of the DEADMAN switches on the back of TP and press RESET.
Hold one of SHIFT keys and press jog key.
Switch to JOINT to move out of singularity.
Hold one of SHIFT keys to move to the recorded point.

STEP.SUBST: Frame numbers indicate the frame number being used. Frames are numbered automatically starting with 1.
Input a comment to further identify the EOAT. The comment can be up to 29 characters.

WIZARD.STEP:
Input the Robot Output port numbers that open or close the EOAT.
Input the Robot Output port number that opens the EOAT.
Input the Robot Output port number that closes the EOAT.

Input the Robot Output port numbers that turn on or off the vacuum.
Enter the Robot Output port number that turns off the vacuum.
Enter the Robot Output port number that turns on the vacuum.

X, Y, Z describes the three-dimensional location of the tool center point relative to the center of the faceplate.
Input the measurement between the center line of the EOAT and the tool center point in the X direction.
Input the measurement between the center line of the EOAT and the Tool Center Point in the Y direction.
Input the measurement from the center of the faceplate of the robot to the point on the tool that performs work.

STEP.SUBST: This is the measurement from the center of the faceplate of the robot to the point on the tool that does the work. Measure this distance and enter it here.

WIZARD.STEP:
The Rotation of a position has three components, (W, P, R), which describe the three-dimensional rotation of the position.
Input the measurement of W which is the rotation of the EOAT about X.
Input the measurement of P which is the rotation of the EOAT about Y.
Input the measurement of R which is the rotation of the EOAT about Z.

Measure your EOAT.
Input the measurement from the center of the faceplate of the robot to the point on the tool that performs work.

Specify the weight of your EOAT and part.
Input the total weight of the EOAT.
Input the total weight of the part.
Input a comment to further identify the payload.
Input a comment to further identify the payload.
Setup EOAT Center of Mass and EOAT with Part Center of Mass.
Enter the Center of Mass for the EOAT and part. This is the balance point of the empty EOAT. The unit is cm. This is the balance point of the EOAT holding the part. The unit is cm.

STEP.text: EOAT X, (Y, Z) Center of Mass
STEP.SUBST: Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the balance point of the EOAT in the X direction. The unit is cm.
Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the balance point of the EOAT in the Y direction. The unit is cm.
Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the balance point of the EOAT in the Z direction. The unit is cm.

STEP.text: EOAT with Part Center of Mass

SUBST.text: EOAT with Part X Center of Mass

STEP.SUBST: Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the "balance point" of the EOAT with part in the X direction. The unit is cm.

SUBST.text: EOAT with Part Y Center of Mass

STEP.SUBST: Input the center of mass in the Y direction. This is the "balance point" of the EOAT with part in the Y direction. The unit is cm.

SUBST.text: EOAT with Part Z Center of Mass

STEP.SUBST: Input the center of mass in the Z direction. This is the "balance point" of the EOAT with part in the Z direction. The unit is cm.

WIZARD.STEP: Congratulations! Your EOAT Setup is complete. Press NEXT STEP to continue.
Please refer MORE INFO below to jog the robot in the tool frame you just taught.

NAME.MENU: Welcome to the End of Arm Tooling (EOAT) setup. In this Guide, you will set up items such as the Tool Center Position, Tool Center of Mass, and I/O signals for the tool attached to the robot.

EOAT Setup Additional Information

EOAT, sometimes called a tool or tooling, is the equipment attatched to your robot that you use to perform work. In this setup you will be specifying details about your kind of tooling, such as EOAT dimensions, angles, and other applicable parameters so that the robot can properly make use of the EOAT. You can return to this setup to change any setting at any time. If you do not want to save your changes, press CANCEL.

Choose the kind of EOAT or tool you are using.
Use finger type gripper.
Use vacuum type gripper.
Dual Gripper - Raw Part
Dual Gripper - Finished Part

Choose the setup method of the tool. You can choose whether you want to enter your EOAT data directly, or use the robot to record the EOAT information.
Input the dimensions of your EOAT directly.
Use the robot to determine the EOAT dimensions.

Choose your EOAT type.
Choose Straight if the point on the EOAT that performs work is centered under the faceplate.
Choose Offset if the point on the EOAT that performs work is off to one side or sticking out from the center of the faceplate.

Choose a method to record the EOAT Frame.
Use the Three Point Method to define the location of the tool frame when the values cannot be measured and directly entered.
Use the four point method to define the precise location of the tool frame.
Use the six point method to define the location and orientation of the tool frame when the values cannot be measured and directly entered. Use XZ when it is easier for you to record a point in the +Z direction.
Use the six point method to define the location and orientation of the tool frame when the values cannot be measured and directly entered. Use the XY when it is easier for you to record a point in the +Y direction.
Use the Two Point + Z method to set the TCP for robots which can not tilt their EOAT to the XY plane in the world frame (i.e. 4 axes robots).

Teach Method Additional Information

Three Point:
The three approach points must be taught with the tool touching a common point from three different approach directions. The Three Point Method of defining the tool frame always places the +Z direction of the frame outward from the faceplate. You cannot use this method to define the tool frame for weaving, Thru-Arc Seam Tracking, or touch sensing if you are using ArcTool.

Four Point:
The Four Point Method requires four approach points to be taught with the tool touching a common point from four different approach positions. This method indicates the approach position with maximum TCP error so that the user can correct that position and re-compute the tool frame. Adjust and re-teach the approach positions that are slightly off iteratively until the tool frame computed is of desired accuracy on the basis of the TCP error feedback. The four point method of defining the tool frame always places the +Z direction of the frame outward from the faceplate. You cannot use this method to define the tool frame for weaving, Thru-Arc Seam Tracking, or touch sensing if you are using ArcTool.

Six Point(XZ):
The six point method requires three points that define the direction vector for the tool, and three points that define the location of the tool center point.

Six Point(XY):
The six point method requires three points that define the direction vector for the tool, and three points that define the location of the tool center point.

Two Point + Z:
Teach the approach point 1 and 2 with the EOAT touching a certain fixed point from two different approach points. X and Y are calculated from these two approach points. Measure the Z value with a ruler, etc. and input the Z value directly. Also, input the W, P, and R values directly. (However, input 0 to all three values when the direction of the faceplate and the direction of the tool attitude are the same.)
Record the first approach point. Select Record the First Point to record the current position as the First Point.

Teach the First Point Additional Information

Record the First Point:
Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Try to align to tool so that it is parallel to the Z of the WORLD coordinate system. When you have finished, select Record the First Point.

Jog Assist:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Record the second approach point. Select Record the Second Point to record the current position as the Second Point.

Teach the Second Point Additional Information

Record the Second Point:
Jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Rotate the tool about the Z axis in WORLD 180 degrees but not more than 360 degrees, if possible. Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches the reference point. Select Record the Second Point.

Jog Assist:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Record the third approach point. Select Record the Third Point to record the current position as the Third Point.

Teach the Third Point Additional Information

Record the Third Point:
Jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Rotate the tool about either the X or Y axis of the WORLD coordinate. Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Select Record the Third Point.

Jog Assist:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Record the forth approach point. Select Record the Fourth Point to record the current position as the Fourth Point.

Teach the Forth Point Additional Information

Record the Forth Point:
Jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Rotate the tool about either the X, Y and/or Z axis of the WORLD coordinate. Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Select Record the Forth Point.

Jog Assist:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Record Orient Origin Point. Select Record Orient Origin Point to record the current position as the Orient Origin Point.

Teach Orient Origin Point Additional Information

Record Orient Origin Point:
To record the orientation of the origin, jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Jog the robot so that the desired tool +Z axis is parallel to the Z axis of the world frame, pointing in the -Z direction. Make sure that the X axis of the tool is parallel to the X axis of the world frame. Using only the X, Y, and Z keys, jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Select Record Orient Origin Point.

Jog Assist:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Record X Direction Point. Select Record X Direction Point to record the current position as the X Direction Point.

Teach X Direction Point Additional Information

Record X Direction Point:
To record the X direction point, jog the robot so that the tool moves in the +X direction at least 250 mm or more. For example, if the X axis of the tool is aligned with the world X axis, jog in the +X direction. Select Record X Direction Point.

Jog Assist:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Record Z Direction Point. Select Record Z Direction Point to record the current position as the Z Direction Point.

Teach Z Direction Point Additional Information

Record Z Direction Point:
To record the Z direction point, jog the robot so that the tool moves in the +Z direction at least 250 mm or more. For example, if the Z axis of the tool is aligned with the world Z axis, jog in the +Z direction. Select Record Z Direction Point.

Jog Assist:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Record Y Direction Point. Select Record Y Direction Point to record the current position as the Y Direction Point.

Teach Y Direction Point Additional Information

Record Y Direction Point:
To record the Y direction point, the robot so that the tool moves in the +Z direction at least 250 mm or more. For example, if the Z axis of the tool is aligned with the world -Z axis, jog in the -Z direction. Select Record Y Direction Point.

Jog Assist:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.

Robot I/O

Inputs and Outputs (I/O) are signals exchanged between devices that allow one piece of equipment to send/receive status signals or commands to/from another piece of equipment. The physical connector through which the I/O signal enters/exits a device is often referred to as a port.

Robot I/O consists of input and output signals between the controller and the robot. RO, therefore, refers to Robot Outputs, whereas RI refers to Robot Inputs. These signals are wired from the robot controller to a connector on the robot labeled EE. EE stands for End Effector. End Effector is a term that typically applies to the EOAT. Robot I/O is usually used to control the robot's tooling.

Macro programs will be created to control the EOAT. If your setup uses Digital Outputs instead of Robot Outputs, then you can modify the macro programs in the VERIFY step.

Offsets (XYZ) Additional Information

X is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the faceplate. The X direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame. Y is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the arm. The Y direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame. Z is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the arm. The Z direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame.

Rotations (WPR) Additional Information

The orientation of a position is expressed as three dimensions, (W, P, R) which are measured in degrees of rotation about the X, Y, and Z axes. For example, 0,-90, 0 means that the position is rotated -90 degrees about the Y axis and is not rotated about the X or Z axes.

Weight Additional Information

For proper robot operation it is very important that the robot has an accurate measurement of the weight that it is carrying. Knowing the part weight and the EOAT weight allows optimal robot response whether or not the part is held by the EOAT.

Center of Mass Additional Information

Center of mass has been defined as the point at which the weighted relative position of the distributed mass sums to zero or the point where if a force is appled causes it to move in the direction of force without rotation. In other words center of mass defines the point at which the mass, that the robot is carrying, balances. This information allows the robot to accelerate appropriately during motion.

EOAT Center of Mass Additional Information

EOAT Center of Mass

EOAT with Part Center of Mass Additional Information

EOAT with Part Center of Mass

EOAT Comment Additional Information

EOAT Comment is extra information regarding the end-of-arm-tool (EOAT). It is composed with the "Tool Frame Number" and a comment.
The "Tool Frame Number" is an ID of a particular frame (coordinate system) assigned for the EOAT. This is set automatically, and you can't change the value in this Guide.
Comment is a 29 character note for the EOAT. Comments are optional, and can be a short memo, or a label for the EOAT.

TCP Verification Additional Information

Rotate the tool about the X axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

Rotate the tool about the Y axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

Rotate the tool about the Z axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

WIZARD.STEP:
Several related views are setup so you can easily view the data created by this wizard.

Press on the title bar for related views or press i + FCTN

Press FINISH to end this wizard.

NAME.MENU: Welcome to the Cell Setup Wizard. You can come back to this Wizard at any time and change any of the setups. In this Wizard you will teach some reference positions and setup the I/O signals which will be used to control the robot.

Home Position

Program the robot to move to the Home Position before the first position, between cycles, and any time the robot must be away from workcell activity. DOUT[1] will turn ON when the robot is close to the Home Position and OFF when away. This position is recorded as the Reference Position[Home Position] and can be viewed in SETUP Ref Position menu.

The program HOME_POSITION is provided to move to this position.

Repair Position

Program the robot to move to the Repair Position when maintenance is required. DOUT[2] will turn ON when the robot is close to the Repair Position and OFF when away. This position is recorded as the Reference Position[Repair Position] and can be viewed in SETUP Ref Position menu.

The program REPAIR_POSITION is provided to move to this position.
Select SOP if you want to operate the robot from the front panel. Select UOP if you want to operate the robot from an external device using digital inputs and outputs.

Your changes have not been saved yet.

Press CANCEL to quit

or

NEXT STEP to create the programs and record the positions.

MENU.MENELE:
The Home Position is a position away from the workpiece transfer area.

Move the robot to an appropriate location and press the record button.

The Home Position is a position away from the workpiece transfer area.

The Home Position has already been recorded. Move the Robot menu will allow you to move to the Home Position.

The Repair Position is a position where robot maintenance operations are performed.

Move the robot to an appropriate location and press the record button.

The Repair Position is a position where robot maintenance operations are performed.

The Repair Position has already been recorded. Move the Robot menu will allow you to move to the Repair Position.

WIZARD.STEP:
Input a program name and comment.
Input a program name to identify the program. The starting character must be a letter.
Input a program comment to further identify the program.

NAME.MENU:
Choose a template to create your program.
Select Blank Template to start with an empty program to which you can add instructions.
Comment1"
Comment2"
Comment3"
Comment4"
Comment5"
Comment6"
Comment7"
Comment8"
Comment9"
Comment10"

Program Name

When you create a new program, you must give it a unique program name. The name should be descriptive and it should tell you what the program does. The name can be from one to 36 characters long, must start with a letter, and it must contain no spaces or special characters other than an underscore.

Program Comment

The comment can be up to 16 characters.

Template Programs

Template programs are sample programs that can be used to create your teach pendant program. They contain default instructions that perform typical robot operations. After you choose a template, it will be copied to a new program to which you can modify or add other instructions.
Check which motion groups the program will control. If the program will not contain any motion, then select No Motion.

Group Information

When you create a program, you define which group of axes, or motion group, that the program will control. Motion groups define different groups of axes that can be used for independent pieces of equipment, positioning tables, opening devices, and other axes. Only those groups configured on your robot will be shown. Select which motion group(s) will be controlled by this program. If you do not select a group, you cannot add motion instructions to your program.

Choose the type of program you want to create.
Typical Robot Program creates a program as a .TP (Teach Pendant) program, which can include almost any instruction available in the robot including motion instructions. This is typical for most operations.
Advanced Program creates a .TP program which can be created for specific motion groups or with no motion. Additional types, such as Job (.JB), Process (.PR), Collection (.CO), Macro (.MC), or Condition (.CH) may be available based on controller settings.
Choose the type of program you want to create.

Program Type Information

Note: Your controller may not have all program types available.

TP Program

TP Program creates a .TP program which can be created for specific motion groups or with no motion.

Job

Job creates a .JB program which can be used as the main program. When you run production, you run the job that corresponds to the task you want to perform. The job contains program calls to each of the processes that will be performed during production.

Process

Process creates a .PR program. A process is a program that directs the robot to perform a specific task.

Collection

Collection creates a .CO program which is used to collect programs together to simplify program maintenance.

Macro

Macro creates a .MC program which can include any instructions and function as a typical .TP program. However, macro programs can be set up to be executed in these unique ways:
  • Pressing a Teach Pendant User Key
  • Selecting an item on the MANUAL FCNTS Macros screen
  • Issuing an input signal: DI, RI, UI, and Marker

Condition

Condition creates a .CH program which will monitor events on the controller and perform actions when the events become true. Only the WHEN instruction is available in a condition program.
We perform the tasks for program teaching of a Pick-and-Place program using the following steps. Perform Create a program first.
Create a program is finished. Proceed to Edit the program.
The Pick-and-Place program you created moves the robot as shown below. Next, jog the robot (manually) to set up the four motion points contained in the program.
Jog the robot to the starting point. You will actually move the robot in the following steps.
Turn the Operator Panel Mode Switch to T1.
Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON. The red button on the upper right corner is the Emergency Stop button. In case of emergency, press this button to immediately stop the robot.
To select the method to move the robot, press the COORD key several times until WORLD appears on the screen.

The DEADMAN switch is a three-position switch used to ensure safe robot operation. Hold one of the DEADMAN switches on the back of the TP to the second (middle) position while you perform the following operation steps.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the RESET key to reset the alarm shown in the status window.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot above the pick point.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -Z(J3) key to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the point to pick up the workpiece.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the pass point for moving to the place point.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the point to place the workpiece.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot. Use +Z(J3) to jog above the place point.
Jog the robot away from the place point.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.
Edit the program is finished. Proceed to Execute the program.
The robot motions you have set up so far are contained in the program shown below. Next, execute the Pick-and-Place program from the first line.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.
If the Step LED is lit, hold the DEADMAN switch and press the STEP key to turn off the Step LED. The continuous execution mode will be selected.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the FWD key to execute the program from beginning to end at once. Keep holding the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key during the program execution.
You have completed the Pick-and-Place program. Select FINISH to enter the TP Editor where you can modify the program and touchup the points.

MENELE.text: Turn the TP Enable switch to ON to edit the program.
Select FINISH to create the new program. You will enter the TP Editor where you can modify the program.
Select FINISH to create the Collection. You will enter the Select menu where you can add programs to the collection.

WIZARD.STEP: To backup your files press NEXT STEP, then press FINISH.

NAME.MENU: Select backup device. If no device appears, insert valid USB stick or Memory Card, then tap [Refresh Device List].

Backup Device Additional Information

Front Panel USB (UD1)

This port is on the front panel of most controllers.

Memory Card (MC)

You need to open the cabinet to access this device slot.

Teach Pendant USB (UT1)

This port is located on the side of the TP.

Select the type of backup you wish to perform. Backup all files. This selection gives you the option to backup specific files. To view and select specific backup files, press NEXT STEP. Perform an Image backup.
Select the files that you want to back up.

Press FINISH to start the backup.
Current Status:

MENU.text: Directory is not empty. All files will be deleted if you finish with this folder selected.
Image Backup requires TP to be enabled and to cycle power on the controller.

NAME.MENU:
Select your geographic region.
Americas
Europe
Asia Pacific

Select the level of Network Accessibility that you want.
All network access is disabled.
The system will get its setup from the network router

Security Information

The robot controller is designed to be open and accessible. Robots should be protected by a Firewall to avoid any unauthorized access. The robot is not intended to be connected directly to a public network. Use care in providing any external access to the robot controller.

The accessibility settings here allow you to provide a certain level of accessibility to prevent inadvertent access to Web Services, KCL Access and FTP Write. These settings should be made based on your particular environment.
Network is not set up. You must select Set Up Network in order to proceed to the next step.
Your network has been set up. Select Change Network Settings to modify network setup.

Network Setup Additional Information

Setting up the network allows you to access the robot from an external device like a PC or tablet. After you set it up, your robot will connect to the network. You must set up your network to continue. If you do not have a network set up at your facility, press PREV STEP and select No Network Access to skip this step.

You can change your access level at any time from the Initial Setup screen. Your setup choices won't be deleted unless you CANCEL the Guide.

Press NEXT STEP or press FINISH to proceed. For novice users, this continues Step-by-step robot setup assistance. Even for expert users, this is an easy way to complete required settings. If you are an expert user and already know how to set up your robot, this exits step-by-step assistance.

Welcome to

Guided Setup

A step-by-step guide to setting up your robot using FANUC's intuitive setup Guides.

Press NEXT STEP to begin or MORE INFO for more information.

MENELE.text:
WARNING:
Unsafe operation of the robot could injure personnel or damage equipment.

NAME.MENU:
Press EXIT to return to iHMI Guides

Please review all applicable safety documentation for your system before you continue.

For more information, press MORE INFO below.

Press NEXT STEP and proceed when you understand the safety considerations.

Safety Information

The owner or user should consult the standards for robots, e.g. ISO 10218 and ANSI/RIA R15.06, to ensure compliance with requests for Robotics System design, usability, operation, maintenance, and service.

Additionally, as the owner, employer, or user of a robotic system, it is your responsibility to arrange for the training of the operator of a robot system to recognize and respond to known hazards associated with your robotic system, and to be aware of and follow the recommended operating procedures for your particular application and robot installation.

iHMI Guides Additional Information

  • You can return to iHMI Guides at any time and change any of your answers.
  • Choosing an item on the screen will display the NEXT STEP key.
  • Press NEXT STEP to continue.
  • Press PREV STEP to return to an earlier answer and change it.
  • You can also select a different step in the iHMI Guides by selecting it in the step pane on the left of the screen.
  • Press CANCEL to quit and the Guide will start over from the beginning.
  • Press FINISH when you have completed a setup, and iHMI Guides will record your settings.
Press EXIT to return to iHMI Guides.

Select editor type.
The Touch Panel Editor (Icon editor) is touch based and easy to use for novice users. This editor requires the touch panel iPendant. Please select the Regular Editor if your iPendant does not have a touch panel.
The regular editor is commonly used by experienced users. If your iPendant doesn't have touch panel, please select this editor.

STEP.SUBST: This is the name of the controller on the network.
This is the IP address in the form 192.168.1.100 please enter with the . using the keypad.
This is the subnet a mask which is typically 255.255.255.0 but might be 255.255.240.0 depending on the subnet size. Ask your system administrator. Please enter with the . using the keypad.
This is the router IP address. Usually it is the same as your IP address, except that the final digit is a 1. This is required if you are accessing a network outside of your local sub-net.
This is the MAC address of the robot controller. It is not settable by the user.
This is the name of the controller on the network.
This is the IP address in the form 192.168.1.100 please use the keyboard to enter the address.
This is the subnet a mask which is typically 255.255.255.0 but might be 255.255.240.0 depending on the subnet size. Ask your system administrator. Please enter with the . using the keypad.
This is the router IP address. Usually it is the same as your IP address except that the final digit is a 1. This is required if you are accessing a network outside of your local sub-net.
This is the MAC address of the robot controller. It is not settable by the user
This is the name of the controller on the network.
This is the IP address in the form 192.168.1.100 please enter with the . using the keypad.
This is the subnet a mask which is typically 255.255.255.0 but might be 255.255.240.0 depending on the subnet size. Ask your system administrator. Please enter with the . using the keypad.
This is the router IP address. Usually it is the same as your IP address except that the final digit is a 1. This is required if you are accessing a network outside of your local sub-net.
This is the MAC address of the robot controller. It is not settable by the user

WIZARD.STEP: Congratulations! Your Initial Setup is complete. Press NEXT STEP to verify that you are connected to the Network.
Your system is getting Network parameters using DHCP. Depending on your Network this may take up to one minute.
Please verify that you can connect to the robot using this Link on another Network Device. Press MORE INFO if you cannot connect.

MENU.text: DHCP was not successful consult with your network administrator if the problem persists.
Ethernet cable is not connected please check the connection
DHCP connect is in progress please wait...
DHCP disable in progress please wait. This may take more than 15 seconds.
Current manual settings will be lost

NAME.MENU: Selecting Manual settings will disble DHCP. Continue?

EtherNet/IP CIP Safety is enabled on the Robot.
A power-cycle is required to change the robot IP address on this interface.
In this Guide, you will set up the Network for one of the Ethernet ports. Press NEXT STEP to start.

Select a method to set up the network.
The system will receive the network setup from the router.
Input the network setup parameters manually.

Network Information

By selecting automatic, the system will search for an IP address from a router or other network service. This IP address is not guaranteed to be the same every time, so consider setting up a static IP address so that the server functions of the robot are always available on the same IP address. This setting is also required for network I/O like EIP or Profinet.

You can still set up and run the robot without setting up the network, but you will not be able to connect to the robot with your Apple, Android or PC device.

Select the level of Network Accessibility that you want. All network access is disabled. This means that you cannot access the Web server, KCL, or PCDK services at all. Normal Web server access is allowed. FTP read is allowed. No access to KCL or PCDK services is allowed. FTP write access is prohibited. Web server, KCL, FTP read and write, and PCDK are accessible. All network capabilities are enabled including external iPendant access.
Choose the selected port for your Ethernet connection. Make sure that an active Ethernet cable is plugged into the selected port before proceeding. Port 3 functionality is limited. Press MORE INFO

If the Enhanced Vision Ethernet Port option (R825) is installed, then the Vision Ethernet Port (CD38C) Port 3 can also be configured. This port is only available when the option is installed.

Ethernet port #3 supports:

  • Vision Ethernet camera
  • FTP File Transfer Protocol
  • HTTP Web Server
Other protocols including DHCP for automatic configuration are NOT supported.

Connect Information

You should be able to connect to the link information(URL) on this page from your smartphone, tablet or PC.

You can connect to the robot on the local network only. You cannot connect from an outside network or LTE connection. If you are connecting through Wi-Fi, the robot must be on the same network as your Wi-Fi access point

If you see this icon, there is an error connecting the robot to the network. Try the step again.

If you still cannot connect please check the following:

  • Did you pay attention to notifications on prior steps?
  • Can you connect to other devices on the network with your device?
  • Are you accessing your local Network?
  • Are you using the IP address in the Robot Link as recommended?
  • Did you manually enter a unique IP address?
  • Did you try powering the robot off and on?
If you wish to connect using the robot name contact you network administrator.

This tutorial guides you to jog (manually move) the robot using the teach pendant (TP).

You will learn to jog the robot in two ways:
- Joint
- Cartesian (X, Y, Z)

We agree that a MORE INFO button on each page would be useful.
Turn the Operator Panel Mode Switch to T1 before you jog the robot.
Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON.
Press the COORD key several times until JOINT appears on the screen.
Check the override speed to make sure it is 10%. If it is not 10%, press the +% or -% key (override key) several times unitl 10% appears.
Hold one of the DEADMAN switches on the back of the TP when you reset an alarm and while you jog a robot.

Finally, hold DEADMAN and press the RESET key to reset alarm.
If you cannot reset it, refer to manuals or ask your adviser.

While holding the DEADMAN and the SHIFT key, press either -X(J1) or +X(J1) key.

* Robot does not move in alarm state.

For J2 to J6 joints, hold DEADMAN and the SHIFT key, then press keys related to each joint.

* Robot does not move in alarm state.
To jog in Cartesian, press the COORD key several times until WORLD appears on the screen.
Press the +% or -% key (override key) several times until 10% appears.

Hold DEADMAN and the SHIFT key, then press the -X(J1) or +X(J1) key.

* Robot does not move in alarm state.

For Y or Z direction, hold DEADMAN and the SHIFT key, then press keys related to each direction.

* Robot does not move in alarm state.

Hold DEADMAN and the SHIFT key, then press the -X(J4) or +X(J4) key.

* Robot does not move in alarm state.

For rotation toward Y or Z, hold DEADMAN and the SHIFT key, then press keys related to each rotation.

* Robot does not move in alarm state.

All steps of jog have completely done.

The next tutorial is "Tutorial - Edit program."

Tap FINISH to go back to HOME and select the next tutorial.

MENELE.text: Robot will move watch the robot!!

NAME.MENU:
This tutorial guides you to create a program using the teach pendant (TP).

You will experience the following:
- Program edit with the guide
- Editing the created program

Note:
You are required to complete "Tutorial - Jog" in advance.
You are going to create a TP program to move the robot as shown below.

To create a program, you have to work on other screens.
You can go back to this tutorial any time by tapping
HOME -> Tutorial buttons.

Start the program creation guide by tapping
HOME -> CREATE PROGRAM buttons.

You are creating a sample program by using a template program.
Select a template by tapping TUTORIAL in the template list.

You can enter program name and comments after checking the template.
But this time, just tap NEXT STEP to use the default name and comment for ease.

You can select a type of the program.
Tap Program with Motion and then tap NEXT STEP.

Check the program name, template, and comment.
Tap FINISH if it looks the same as in the figure below.

Program creation has finished.
Tap HOME -> Tutorial buttons to go back to the tutorial.

Edit the program in the program editor.
Press the EDIT key to open the editor.
The editing program is automatically stored each time you make a change.
To go back to the tutorial, tap HOME -> Tutorial buttons.
Jog the robot to a position where the robot motion (program) starts from.

Place a cursor on the "J P[1]" line.
Hold the SHIFT key and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the position.

When the position is recorded, the number of P[1] turns to black and "@" appears on the left of P[1].
Jog the robot forward as below.

Place a cursor on the "L P[2]" line.
Hold SHIFT key and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the position.

When the position is recorded, the number of P[2] turns to black and "@" appears on the left of P[2].
Jog the robot to side as below.

Place a cursor on the "L P[3]" line.
Hold SHIFT key and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the position.

When the position is recorded, the number of P[3] turns to black and "@" appears on the left of P[3].
Jog the robot back near the home position you have set.

Place a cursor on the "L P[4]" line.
Hold the SHIFT key and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the position.

When the position is recorded, the number of P[4] turns to black and "@" appears on the left of P[4].
Program editing has finished. Tap HOME -> Tutorial buttons to go back to the tutorial.

All steps of edit program have completely done.

The next tutorial is " Tutorial - Program execution."

Tap FINISH to go back to HOME and select the next tutorial.

This tutorial guides you to execute the robot program you have created.

You will experience the following:
- Single step execution
- Continuous test execution

Note:
You are required to complete "Tutorial - Program edit" in advance.
Tap HOME -> Resent Programs button to show a program list. Or just click the most recent program in the home screen. You can go back to this tutorial any time by tapping HOME -> Tutorial button.

Tap the "TUTORIAL" program you have created.
The program editor will open and the program will be shown.
Press +% or -% key (override key) several times until 10% appears.
Touch first line of program or use arrow keys to select the first line of the program.
Press STEP to select the single step execution mode and turn on the Step LED on the screen.

Hold DEADMAN and SHIFT key, then press FWD key repeatedly until the last line of the program.

* Robot does not move in alarm state.
After checking override is 10%, press STEP and turn off the Step LED to start the continuous mode.

Hold DEADMAN and SHIFT key, then press FWD key to execute the program from beginning to end at once.

* Robot does not move in alarm state.

All steps of program execution have completely done.

Now you have finished whole contents of the tutorial.
